document_title: Hyperuricemia: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
Hyperuricemia is a condition in which the uric acid index in the blood is abnormally high, occurring when the body decomposes excessive purines or fails to eliminate uric acid from the body. Increased uric acid is an alarming health condition that can lead to permanent bone and joint damage, tophi deposits under the skin, as well as increase the risk of heart and kidney disease. (first)
Uric acid is a metabolite found in the blood, a product of purine metabolism in the human body and is eliminated mainly from the kidneys (80%) and partly through the intestines (20%). Uric acid levels in the blood will also increase or decrease depending on the diet. Uric acid levels will increase when consuming large amounts of purines in the body such as red meat, shellfish, alcohol, etc.
In addition, blood uric acid levels also increase in cases of kidney damage such as kidney failure, reducing uric acid excretion from the body. Genetic mutations that affect purine metabolism and uric acid excretion also cause this condition.
Increasing blood uric acid above the saturation threshold of uric acid will cause deposition of MSU (monosodium urate) crystals in tissues such as joint tissue, subcutaneous tissue, kidney tubules, blood vessels... Gout is a manifestation of increased uric acid. lengthen. Deposition and formation of MSU crystals can lead to arthritis with symptoms such as swelling, heat, redness, and pain in the joints. In addition, deposition in the kidneys can form kidney stones.
